block.p: U.S. Official Says Hezbollah Trained Some Iraqi Militias A senior American intelligence official said that between 1,000 and 2,000 fighters from the Mahdi Army and other Shiite militia groups from Iraq had been trained by Hezbollah in Lebanon. A small number of Hezbollah operatives have also visited Iraq to help with training there, the official said.

Australia Kickbacks for Hussein A high-level commission investigating corruption in the United Nations oil-for-food program released a report stating unequivocally that a major Australian wheat company paid more than $224 million in kickbacks and bribes to Saddam Hussein's government.

3 Sent for Poison Test in Britain Three people in London complaining of symptoms consistent with the radiation poisoning that killed a former Russian spy, Alexander Litvinenko, have been sent to a special clinic here for further tests, the authorities said, cautioning that the danger was minimal.

Obstruction Cited in China Trial A Chinese legal expert who exposed abuses in the country's population control policies began a rare second trial, but his lawyers accused local authorities of preventing them from mounting a vigorous defense.

Bush and Aides Travel to Jordan As President Bush and his top diplomats try to halt the downward spiral in Iraq and Lebanon, they seem intent on their strategy of talking only to Arab friends, despite increasing calls inside and outside the administration for them to reach out to Iran and Syria as well.

Israeli's Offer to Palestinians Prime Minister Ehud Olmert, trying to build on a shaky cease-fire in the Gaza Strip, offered Palestinians incentives, including negotiations and a prisoner release, if they turned away from violence.

Review of Spy Program Is Begun by Justice Dept. After months of pressure from Congressional Democrats, the Justice Department's inspector general said his office had opened a full review into the department's role in President Bush's domestic eavesdropping program and the legal requirements of the program.

Fire at Group Home Kills 10 A fire raced through a group home for the mentally ill and disabled in southwestern Missouri, killing nine residents and one staff member in a blaze that Gov. Matt Blunt called suspicious.

Atlanta Policemen Put on Leave Police Chief Richard J. Pennington of Atlanta placed all eight members of a narcotics investigation team on leave after a confidential informant said they had asked him to lie during the investigation into the death of an 88-year-old woman who was killed by officers during a drug raid.

Court Rules Against The Times The United States Supreme Court refused to stop a federal prosecutor from reviewing the telephone records of two reporters for The New York Times. The records, the newspaper said, include information about many of the reporters' confidential sources.

Christian Coalition Leader Quits The president-elect of the Christian Coalition of America, the Rev. Joel C. Hunter has stepped down saying the group resisted his efforts to broaden its agenda to include reducing poverty and fighting global warming.

G.O.P. Wins Ohio House Race Representative Deborah Pryce, a Republican leader in the House, was named the winner in her Congressional race after the last provisional ballots were counted. But the 1,054-vote margin of victory -- less than one-half of 1 percent -- will set off an automatic recount.

'Excessive Force' Used In Shooting, Mayor Says Mayor Bloomberg convened an extraordinary meeting of black religious leaders and elected officials at City Hall to calm frayed tempers over the fatal police shooting of an unarmed black man in Queens, a killing he called ''inexplicable'' and ''unacceptable.'' ''It sounds to me like excessive force was used,'' the mayor said.

Plans to Close N.Y. Hospitals A New York State commission plans to close at least nine hospitals, including five in New York City , in an effort to cut the state's health care costs. The plan is one of the biggest efforts ever to overhaul the state's troubled health care system.

Assembly Lists Pet Projects The New York Assembly made public its full list of pet legislative projects, giving taxpayers the clearest view yet of how lawmakers have spent $85 million a year on thousands of local initiatives that critics have derided as pork-barrel spending. But a lawyer for a newspaper that sued to get the documents said they were unusable.

Whitney's Plans Shift South A month after the Dia Art Foundation scrapped its plans to open a museum at the entrance to the High Line, the abandoned elevated railway line that the city is transforming into a public park, the Whitney Museum of American Art has signed on to take its place and build a satellite institution of its own downtown.
Bebe Moore Campbell A best-selling novelist known for her empathetic treatment of the difficult, intertwined and occasionally surprising relationship between the races, she was 56.

Stocks Fall on Retail Data Stocks tumbled in their steepest slide since July, after a weak sales estimate by Wal-Mart spurred concerns about the holiday shopping season and fed broader worries about a slowing economy.
Editorials: Global warming goes to court; slouching toward Riga; 50 bullets and a death in Queens; holiday defenses breached.
Columns: Thomas B. Edsall, Nicholas D. Kristof.
